qText:
You are about to participate in a dual-task study.

PRIMARY TASK: Answer the grammar questions presented on screen.

SECONDARY TASK: A large button will occasionally appear randomly on the screen. You must click it AS FAST AS POSSIBLE whenever you see it.

Grammar is the study of the rules of grammatical structure.
A right-to-left grammar is a sentence structure in which the subject precedes the verb.
A left-to-right grammar is a sentence structure in which the verb precedes the subject.
'I ate an apple.' is a left-to-right sentence.
'An apple was eaten by me.' is what kind of grammar?

What kind of grammar is this?
'To school, I went.'
Write a right-to-left grammar sentence expressing someone eating something.
Write a left-to-right grammar sentence expressing someone walking an animal.
Write a left-to-right grammar sentence expressing someone eating something.
Write a right-to-left grammar sentence expressing someone eating something.

We will now look at 'Grammars'.

In this context, a Grammar is just a rule for how to build a line of text.

Some rules add characters to the Left side. Some rules add characters to the Right side.

Imagine a rule where you must always add new blocks to the RIGHT side of a line.

Start: [A]
Step 1: [A]+[A]
Step 2: [A][A]+[A]

Is this rule building TO the Left or the Right?

In grammars, we use a Capital Letter (like 'S') to mark the 'active' side where new things are added.

If the rule is: S -> aS

The 'S' is on the Right side. This means it is a Right-Linear Grammar.

Based on this, where does the 'S' sit in a Left-Linear Grammar?

Look at this specific rule:

A -> Ab

The Capital Letter 'A' (the active part) is on the Left side of the little 'b'.

Is this a Left-Linear or Right-Linear grammar?
If a grammar adds new letters to the far end of the string, effectively growing the word from left-to-right, we call it a ______-Linear Grammar.
